books.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:1
verses.text: Book III.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:2
verses.text: Epistle I.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:3
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:4
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, Subdeacon of Campania.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:5
verses.text: What a crime has been committed in the Lucullan fort against our brother and fellow-bishop Paul the account which has been sent to us has made manifest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:6
verses.text: And, inasmuch as the magnificent Scholasticus, judge of Campania, happens at the present time to be with us here, we have especially enjoined on him the duty of visiting the madness of so great perversity with strict correction.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:7
verses.text: But, since the bearer of the aforesaid account has requested us to send some one to represent ourselves, we therefore send the subdeacon Epiphanius, who, together with the aforesaid judge, may be able to investigate and ascertain by whom the sedition was raised or investigated, and to visit it with suitable punishment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:8
verses.text: Let thy Experience then make haste to give aid in this case with all thy power, to the end both that the truth may be ascertained, and that vengeance may proceed against the guilty parties.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:9
verses.text: Wherefore, since the slaves of the glorious Clementina are said to have had to do with this same crime, and to have used language calculated to stir up the sedition, do thou subject them strictly to immediate punishment, nor let your severity be relaxed in consideration of her person, since they ought to be smitten all the more as they have transgressed out of mere pride as being the servants of a noble lady.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:10
verses.text: But you ought also to make thorough enquiry whether the said lady was privy to so atrocious a crime, and whether it was perpetrated with her knowledge, that from our visitation of it all may learn how dangerous it is not only to lay hands on a priest, but even to transgress in words against one.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:11
verses.text: For, if anything should be done remissly or omitted in this case, know that thou especially wilt have to bear the blame and the risk; nor wilt thou find any plea for excuse with us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:12
verses.text: For in proportion as this business will commend thee to us if it be most strictly investigated and corrected, know that our indignation will become sharp against thee, if it be smoothed over.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:13
verses.text: Moreover, for the rest, if any slaves from the city should have taken refuge in the monastery of Saint Severinus, or in any other church of this same fort, as soon as this has come to thy knowledge, by no means allow them to remain there, but let them be brought to the church within the city; and, if they should have just cause of complaint against their masters, they must needs leave the church with suitable arrangements made for them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 1:14
verses.text: But, if they should have committed any venial fault, let them be restored without delay to their masters, the latter having taken oath to pardon them.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:1
verses.text: Epistle II.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:2
verses.text: To Paulus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:3
verses.text: Gregory to Paulus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:4
verses.text: Although it has distressed us in no slight degree to hear of the injury that thou hast suffered, yet we have matter of consolation in learning that the affair is to thy credit, in that, so far as the account sent to us has disclosed the facts, thou hast suffered in the cause of uprightness and equity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:5
verses.text: Wherefore, that it may redound to the greater glory of thy Fraternity, this occurrence ought neither to shake thy constancy nor turn thee aside from the way of truth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:6
verses.text: For it is to the greater reward of priests if they continue in the path of truth even after injuries.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:7
verses.text: But, lest the madness of such great impiety should remain unpunished, and pernicious insubordination break out to a worse degree, we have enjoined the magnificent Scholasticus, judge of Campania, who is at present here, that he should avenge what has been done with the repression it deserves.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 2:8
verses.text: But, inasmuch as thy men have requested us to commission some one to represent ourselves, know that we have for this reason sent to Naples the subdeacon Epiphanius, who may  be able, with the judge above named, to investigate and ascertain the truth, to the end that by his instancy he may cause worthy vengeance to be executed on those who may be shewn to have instigated or perpetrated so great a crime.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:1
verses.text: Epistle III.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:2
verses.text: To John, Abbot.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:4
verses.text: Thy Love has requested me that brother Boniface might be ordained Prior (praepositus) in thy monastery; as to which request I wonder much why it has not been done before.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:5
verses.text: For since the time when I caused him to be given to thee thou oughtest already to have ordained him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:6
verses.text: With regard to the tunic of Saint John, I have been altogether gratified by thy anxiety to tell me of it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:7
verses.text: But let thy Love endeavour to send me this tunic, or (better still) this same bishop who has it, with his clergy and with the tunic itself, to the end that we may enjoy the blessing thereof, and be able to derive benefit from this bishop and his clergy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:8
verses.text: I have been desirous of putting an end to the cause that is pending with Florianus, and have already advanced to him as much as eighty solidi, which I believe he proposes should be given him in compensation for the monastery's debt; and I am altogether desirous that this cause should be settled, inasmuch as Stephen the chartularius is said to be urgent that the aforesaid Florianus should transfer it to public cognizance, and it is distasteful to us to be engaged in a public lawsuit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:9
verses.text: Wherefore we must needs make some concession, so as to be able to bring this same cause to a composition.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:10
verses.text: When this shall have been done, we will inform your Love of it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:11
verses.text: But do thou give thy whole attention to the souls of the brethren.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:12
verses.text: Let it be now enough that the reputation of the monastery has been stained through your negligence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:13
verses.text: Do not often go abroad.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:14
verses.text: Appoint an agent for these causes, and do thou leave thyself time for reading and prayer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:15
verses.text: Be attentive to hospitality; as far as thou art able, give to the poor; yet so as to keep what ought to be restored to Florianus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:16
verses.text: Moreover, among the brethren of thy monastery whom I see I do not find addiction to reading.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:17
verses.text: Wherefore you must needs consider how great a sin it is, that God should have sent you alimony from the offerings of others, and you should neglect learning the commandments of God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:18
verses.text: Further, with regard to the six twelfths, unless we see the original deed, or a copy of it, we can do nothing.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 3:19
verses.text: But I have sent an order to the servant of God, Florentinus, that, if the truth should be made apparent to him, he restore to you the six twelfths; after the restoration of which we will either grant the remaining six twelfths on lease or commute the revenue.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 4

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 4:1
verses.text: Epistle V.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 4:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 4:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, Subdeacon of Campania.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 4:4
verses.text: As we have no wish to disturb the privileges of laymen in their judgments, so, when they judge wrongfully, we desire thee to resist them with moderate authority.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 4:5
verses.text: For to restrain violent laymen is not to act against the laws, but to support law.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 4:6
verses.text: Since then Deusdedit, the son-in-law of Felix of Orticellum, is said to have done violent wrong to the bearer of these presents, and still unlawfully to detain her property, in such sort that the dejection of her widowhood is found not to move his compassion, but to confirm his malice, we charge thy Experience that against the aforesaid man, as well as in other cases wherein the aforesaid woman asserts that she suffers prejudice, thou afford her the succour of thy protection, and not allow her to be oppressed by any one whatever, lest either thou be found to neglect what without prejudice to equity is commanded thee, or widows and other poor persons, finding no help where they are, be put to expense by the length of the journey hither.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:1
verses.text: Epistle VI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, bishop of Prima Justiniana.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:4
verses.text: After the long afflictions which Adrian, bishop of the city of Thebae, has endured from his fellow-priests, as though they had been his enemies, he has fled for refuge to the Roman city.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:5
verses.text: And though his first representation had been against John, bishop of Larissa, to wit that in pecuniary causes he had given judgment without regard to the laws, yet after this he complained most grievously rather against the person of thy Fraternity, accusing thee of having deposed him unjustly from the degree of priesthood.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:6
verses.text: But we, giving no credence to petitions that have not been enquired into, perused the acts of the proceedings, whether before our brother and fellow-bishop John, or before thy Fraternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:7
verses.text: And indeed concerning the judgment of the above-named John, bishop of Larissa, which was suspended on appeal, both the most pious emperors, in their orders sent to the bishop of Corinth, have sufficiently decreed, and we have decreed also, Christ helping us, in our letters directed through the bearers of these presents to the aforesaid John of Larissa.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:8
verses.text: But having ventilated the conflicting judgments, the examination of which the imperial commands had committed to thee, and inspected the series of proceedings held before the bishop John concerning the incriminated persons, we find that thou hast investigated almost nothing pertaining to the questions named and assigned to thee for decision, but by certain machinations hast produced witnesses against the deacon Demetrius, who were to allege with a view to the condemnation of this same bishop, that they had heard this Demetrius bearing testimony concerning the said bishop;â€”a thing not even lawful to be heard of.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:9
verses.text: And when Demetrius in person denied having done so, it appears that, contrary to the custom of the priesthood and canonical discipline, thou gavest him into the hands of the praetor of the province as a deacon deposed from his dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:10
verses.text: And when, mangled by many stripes, he might perchance have said some things falsely against his bishop under the pressure of torment, we find that to the very end of the business he confessed absolutely nothing of the things about which he was interrogated.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:11
verses.text: Neither do we find anything else in the proceedings themselves, whether in the depositions of witnesses or in the declaration of Adrian, to his disadvantage.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:12
verses.text: But it is only that thy Fraternity, I know not with what motive, in contempt of law, human and divine, has pronounced an abrupt sentence against him; which, even though it had not been suspended on appeal, being pronounced in contravention of the laws and canons, could not rightly in itself have stood.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:13
verses.text: Further, after, as is abundantly evident, the appeal had been handed to thee, we wonder why thou hast not sent thy people to us to render an account of thy judgment according to the undertaking delivered to our deacon Honoratus by the representatives of thy church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:14
verses.text: This omission convicts thee either of contumacy or of trepidation of conscience.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:15
verses.text: If, then, these things which have been brought before us have the rampart of truth, inasmuch as we consider that, taking advantage of your vicariate jurisdiction under us, you are presuming unjustly, we will, with the help of Christ, decree further concerning these things, according to the result of our deliberations.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:16
verses.text: But as regards the present, by the authority of the blessed Peter, Prince of the apostles, we decree that, the decrees of thy judgment being first annulled and made of none effect, thou be deprived of holy communion for the space of thirty days, so as to implore pardon of our God for so great transgression with the utmost penitence and tears.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:17
verses.text: But, if we should come to know that thou hast been remiss in carrying out this our sentence, know thou that not the injustice only, but also the  contumacy, of thy Fraternity will have to be more severely punished.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 5:18
verses.text: But, as to our aforesaid brother and fellow-bishop Adrian, condemned by thy sentence, which, as we have said, was consistent with neither canons nor laws, we order that he be restored, Christ being with him, to his place and rank; so that neither may he be injured by the sentence of thy Fraternity pronounced in deviation from the path of justice, nor may thy Charity remain uncorrected; that so we may appease the indignation of the future judge.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:1
verses.text: Epistle VII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, bishop of Larissa.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:4
verses.text: Our brother Adrian, bishop of the city of Thebae, has come to Rome, bitterly complaining of having been condemned, neither lawfully nor canonically, on certain charges by thy Fraternity, and also by John, bishop of Prima Justiniana.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:5
verses.text: And, when for a long time we saw no representative of the opposite party arrive here who might have replied to his objections, we delivered for perusal, with a view to the necessary ascertainment of the truth, the proceedings which had taken place before you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:6
verses.text: From these we ascertained that John and Cosmas, deacons who had been deposed from their office, one for frailty of the body and the other for fraudulent dealing with ecclesiastical property, had sent a representation to our most pious emperors against him, with respect to pecuniary matters and also criminal charges.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:7
verses.text: They, in their commands sent to thee, desired thee (that is with strict observance of law and canons) to take cognizance of the matter so as to pass a sentence firm in law as to the pecuniary questions, but, as to the criminal charges, to report to their Clemency after a searching examination.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:8
verses.text: Now if thy Fraternity had received in a right frame of mind these such right commands, you would never have accepted for a general accusation of their bishop men removed from their own office for their transgressions, and already hostilely disposed; especially as by their representation addressed to our most pious lords their untruthfulness is detected, in that they declared that they made it with the consent of all the clergy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:9
verses.text: Yet after this, to touch briefly and summarily on some of the proceedings before thee, the first head of accusation was concerning the Theban deacon Stephen, whom the bishop Adrian had failed to deprive of the dignity of his order, though supposed to have been aware of his most shameful life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:10
verses.text: As to this head, no witnesses were produced to show that bishop Adrian had any knowledge of the matter, except that Stephen alone, a man of shameful life and on his own confession to be condemned, is alleged to have said so.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:11
verses.text: The second charge made against him appears to have been concerning infants having been debarred by his order from receiving holy baptism, and so having died with the filth of sin unwashed away.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:12
verses.text: But none of the witnesses brought forward against him declared their knowledge of anything of the kind having come under the notice of bishop Adrian, but said that they had learnt it from the mothers of the infants, whose husbands, it is said, had been removed from the church for their crimes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:13
verses.text: But even so they did not declare that the hour of death had overtaken those infants while unbaptized, as was contained in the invidious representation of the accusers, it being evident that they had been baptized in the city of Demetrias.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:14
verses.text: So much then for the criminal charges.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:15
verses.text: But, as to the pecuniary matters, after what manner they were adjudged by thee is attested by the enquiry of the men deputed by the prince in pursuance of the most pious order of the most serene princes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:16
verses.text: For, when the oft-named Adrian had appealed against thy sentence, then, so far as we have ascertained from the depositions of four witnesses which were laid before John, bishop of Prima Justiniana, he was thrust into most close confinement, and forced by thy Fraternity to produce a document in which he confessed the charges brought against him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:17
verses.text: And it is true that in the document so produced by him he is found to have assented to thy sentence as to pecuniary matters.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:18
verses.text: But the criminal charges he touched on in an indefinite and dubious sort of way, so that both thy purpose might be frustrated by the raising of certain clouds, and he might afterwards the better escape from his confession in the obscurity of a perplexed mode of speech.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:19
verses.text: And when the appeal handed in by his people, and the rest of the proceedings under thy cognizance, had been reported to the most pious princes, and Honoratus, deacon of our See, with the glorious antigraphus Sebastian having been deputed, as we have said, he was exempted by the most serene lords from all further orders.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:20
verses.text: But, by  what sought out contrivances I know not, another imperial order was again elicited, requiring John, bishop of Prima Justiniana, to enquire closely and pass judgment concerning all the aforesaid charges.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:21
verses.text: In which trial all bishop Adrian's clergy, and Demetrius the deacon, the latter in the midst of torments, declared that all this calumny against bishop Adrian had been got up by the contrivance of thy Fraternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:22
verses.text: Nor were any of the criminal charges that had been made in thy audience against the bishop Adrian proved.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:23
verses.text: But there came up, contrary to canons and laws, another cruel and crafty enquiry directed against his deacon Demetrius and other persons, in the course of which nothing was discovered for which the oft-mentioned Adrian could have been lawfully condemned, but rather ground for his acquittal.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:24
verses.text: But with respect to John, prelate of the city of Prima Justiniana, and his most iniquitous and abominable judgment, we shall take further measures.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:25
verses.text: As to bishop Adrian, we find both that he has laboured under thy enmity in a way ill-befitting thy priestly character, and that he has been condemned in pecuniary matters for no just cause by the sentence of thy Fraternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:26
verses.text: Since then, having been deposed also by the above-said John bishop of Prima Justiniana in contravention of law and canons, he could not be left deprived of his rank and honour, we have decreed that he be reinstated in his church, and recalled to the order of his proper dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:27
verses.text: And, though thou oughtest to have been deprived of the communion of the Lord's body, for that, setting at naught the admonition of my predecessor of holy memory, whereby he exempted him and his church from the jurisdiction of thy authority, thou hast again presumed to retain some jurisdiction over them, yet we, decreeing more humanely, and still allowing thee the sacrament of communion, decree that thy Fraternity shall abstain from all exercise of the jurisdiction formerly held by thee over him and his church; but that, according to the written instructions of our predecessor, if any case should possibly arise, whether touching the faith, or criminal, or pecuniary, against the aforesaid Adrian our fellow-priest, it be either taken cognizance of, if the question be a slight one, by those who are or may be our representatives in the royal city, or, if it be an arduous one, it be brought hither to the Apostolic See, to the end that it may be heard and decided before ourselves.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:28
verses.text: But, if thou shouldest attempt at any time, on any pretext or by any surreptitious device, to contravene these our ordinances, know that we decree thee to be deprived of holy communion, and not to partake of it except at the close of thy life, unless upon leave granted by the Roman pontiff.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:29
verses.text: For this we lay down as a rule, agreeably to the teaching of the holy fathers, that whosoever knows not how to obey the holy canons, neither is he worthy to minister or receive the communion at the holy altars.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:30
verses.text: Moreover let thy Fraternity restore to him without any delay the sacred property, or any other, movable or immovable, which thou art said to retain so far; a specification whereof, that has been handed to us, we append to this letter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 6:31
verses.text: Concerning which if any question arises between you, we desire it to be considered by our representative in the royal city.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:1
verses.text: Epistle VIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:2
verses.text: To Natalis, Archbishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:3
verses.text: Gregory to Natalis, archbishop of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:4
verses.text: Whilst every kind of business demands anxious investigation of the truth, what pertains to deposition from sacerdotal rank should be considered with especial strictness, since here the matter in hand is not concerning persons constituted in a humble position, but, as it were, concerning reversal of divine benediction.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:5
verses.text: This consideration has also moved us to exhort your Fraternity with respect to the person of Florentius, bishop of the city of Epidaurus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:6
verses.text: For indeed we have been told that he had been accused on certain criminal charges, and that, without any canonical proof being sought, and without previous sentence of any sacerdotal council, he has been deposed from his office of dignity, not by law, but by authority.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:7
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as no man can be removed from the rank of episcopacy except for just causes by the concordant sentence of priests, we exhort your Fraternity to cause the aforesaid man to be recalled from the banishment into which he has been driven, and his case enquired into in a consultation of bishops.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:8
verses.text: And, should he be convicted by canonical proof of the charges brought against him, without doubt he must be visited with canonical punishment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:9
verses.text: But, should the facts be found by the synodical inquisition to be otherwise than had been supposed, it is necessary both that his accusers should dread the rigour of justice, and that the incriminated person should have the approbation of his innocence preserved inviolate.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 7:10
verses.text: But we have committed by our order the execution of the above-mentioned business to Antoninus, our subdeacon, to the end that decisions may be come to in accordance with the laws and  canons, and, with the help of the Lord, be carried into effect.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:1
verses.text: Epistle IX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:2
verses.text: To Antoninus, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:3
verses.text: Gregory to Antoninus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:4
verses.text: It has come to our ears that Florentius, bishop of the city of Epidaurus, his property having first been seized, has been condemned, for certain crimes not proved, without a sacerdotal council.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:5
verses.text: And, inasmuch as he ought not to suffer canonical punishment, no canonical sentence having been pronounced for his condemnation, we enjoin thy Experience to urge upon our brother and fellow-bishop Natalis that he should cause the aforesaid man to be recalled from the banishment into which he is said to have been driven.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:6
verses.text: And a council of bishops having been assembled, if the charges brought against him should be canonically proved, we will that the sentence of our aforesaid brother and fellow-bishop Natalis shall take effect against him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:7
verses.text: But, should he be absolved by a general judgment, thou must not permit him to be subject to prejudice on the part of any one, and must carefully and rigorously insist on his aforesaid property being restored to him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 8:8
verses.text: It is therefore needful that the heavier thou feelest the burden of such negotiations to be, with the maturer and more vigilant execution thou take pains to fulfil them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:1
verses.text: Epistle X.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:2
verses.text: To Savinus, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:3
verses.text: Gregory to Savinus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:4
verses.text: Bad men have gone forth and disturbed your minds, understanding neither what they say nor whereof they affirm, pretending that in the times of Justinian of pious memory something was detracted from the faith of the holy synod of Chalcedon, which with all faith and all devotion we venerate.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:5
verses.text: And in like manner all the four synods of the holy universal Church we receive as we do the four books of the holy Gospel.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:6
verses.text: But concerning the persons with respect to whom something had been done after the close of the synod, there was something ventilated in the times of Justinian of pious memory: yet so that neither was the faith in any respect violated, nor anything else done with regard to these same persons but what had been determined at the same holy synod of Chalcedon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:7
verses.text: Moreover, we anathematize any one who presumes to detract anything from the definition of the faith which was promulgated in the said synod, or, as though by amending it, to change its meaning: but, as it was there promulged, so in all respects we guard it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 9:8
verses.text: Thee, therefore, most dear son, it becomes to return to the unity of Holy Church, that thou mayest end thy days in peace; lest the malignant spirit, who cannot prevail against thee through thy other works, may from this cause find a way at the day of thy departure of barring thy entrance into the heavenly Kingdom.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 10

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 10:1
verses.text: Epistle XII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 10:2
verses.text: To Maximianus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 10:3
verses.text: Gregory to Maximianus, bishop of Syracuse  I wrote some time ago to your Fraternity desiring you to send to the Roman city those who had alleged anything against Gregory, bishop of the city of Agrigentum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 10:4
verses.text: And we exhort you by this present epistle that this should be immediately done.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 10:5
verses.text: Wherefore hasten to send with speed the persons themselves, and the rest of the documents, that is the reports of proceedings and the petitions that have been given in.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 10:6
verses.text: Nor do we allow any delay or excuse to be sought; to the end that, when they have been sent, as we have said, with speed to the Roman city, we may know how, with the help of God, we may most advantageously deal with him.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:1
verses.text: Epistle XV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:2
verses.text: To Scholasticus, Judge.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:3
verses.text: Gregory to Scholasticus, judge of Campania.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:4
verses.text: While we were greatly distressed in our care for the city of Naples, bereaved of the solace of a priest, the arrival of the bearers of these presents with the decree for the election of our subdeacon Florentius, had afforded us some relief under so great a burden of thought.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:5
verses.text: But, when it appeared that our said subdeacon, flying from the very city, had deprecated his ordination with tears, know ye that our sadness  increased, as if from some heavier dispensation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:6
verses.text: Wherefore, greeting you well, we exhort your Greatness to assemble the chief men or the people of the city, so as to take thought for the election of another, who may be worthy to be promoted to the priesthood with the consolation of Christ.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:7
verses.text: Then, the decree having been solemnly passed, and transmitted to this city, let the ordination proceed, with the help of Christ, among yourselves.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:8
verses.text: But, should you not find a suitable person on whom you can agree, at any rate choose ye three upright and wise men, to be sent to this city as representing the community, and to whose judgment the whole population may assent.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 11:9
verses.text: Perhaps, when they come hither, they will find such a one as may be ordained as your bishop without reproach, to the end that your bereaved city may neither within itself want an inspector of its deeds, nor, when the care of a priest is supplied to it, afford entrance to hostile snares from without.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:1
verses.text: Epistle XXII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:2
verses.text: To Antoninus, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:3
verses.text: Gregory to Antoninus, Subdeacon, Rector of the patrimony in Dalmatia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:4
verses.text: It is commonly reported in these parts that our brother and fellow-bishop, Natalis of the Church of Salona, is dead.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:5
verses.text: If this is true, let thy Experience with all speed and all care hasten to admonish the clergy and people of that city that with one consent they elect a priest for ordination; and, when the nomination of the person who may be elected has been made, thou wilt take care to transmit it to us, that he may be ordained with our consent, as has been the case from ancient times.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:6
verses.text: And this above all things thou must look to, that in this election neither any bribery in any way whatever come in, nor the patronage of any persons whatever prevail.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:7
verses.text: For if one is elected through the patronage of certain persons, he is obliged out of deference to them to comply with their wishes after his ordination, and so it comes to pass that the possessions of that church are lessened, and ecclesiastical order is not maintained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:8
verses.text: They must, therefore, under thy superintendence, elect such a person as will not be unsuitably subservient to the will of any one, but one who in the adornment of his life and conversation may be found worthy of such a high degree.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:9
verses.text: But of the possessions or ornaments of the same church cause an inventory to be faithfully written out in thy presence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:10
verses.text: And, lest any of the possessions themselves should be lost, admonish Respectus the deacon and Stephanus the chief notary (primicerium notariarum) to take sole charge of these possessions, warning them that they will have to make good out of their own substance any diminution of them that may have arisen from their negligence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:11
verses.text: Moreover, strictly charge Malchus, our brother and fellow-bishop, that he refrain entirely from intermeddling in this matter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:12
verses.text: For, should we learn that anything has been done or attempted by him against our will, let him know that he will incur no slight guilt and danger.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:13
verses.text: But of this also take care to warn him, that he must be careful to set down and complete the accounts of our patrimony which he has had in charge; for doing which let him make haste, laying aside all excuses, to come to us from the Sicilian parts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:14
verses.text: Let him, then, in no wise presume to meddle with the affairs of the Church of Salona, lest he should be under further liability to it, and possibly found culpable.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:15
verses.text: For he is said to have many things belonging to the aforesaid church; and report goes that he was well-nigh the prime mover in the sale of its possessions, and in other unlawful doings.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:16
verses.text: And, should this be found in manifest truth to be as it is said to be, he may be certain that it will by no means remain unavenged.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:17
verses.text: Let any necessary expenses be defrayed by the steward who was in office at the time of the aforesaid bishop's death, that so he may explain his accounts to the future bishop as he knows them to be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 12:18
verses.text: All the things that we have enjoined on thee to be done it is certainly necessary that thou shouldest do with the advice of our son, the magnificent and most eloquent Marcellus, to the end that thou mayest be able to carry out carefully and effectively all that is contained in this paper of directions, and that no blame for negligence may belong to thee.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:1
verses.text: Epistle XXIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:2
verses.text: To the Presbyters and Clergy of Mediolanum (Milan).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:3
verses.text: Gregory to the presbyters, deacons, and clergy of the church of Mediolanum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:4
verses.text: We have received your Love's epistle, which, though it bore no subscription, was accredited by the persons of the bearers, the presbyter Magnus and the cleric Hippolytus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:5
verses.text: Having read it, we find that you are all agreed in favour of our son Constantius, deacon of your church, who has been well known to me for long.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:6
verses.text: And, when I represented the Apostolical See in the royal city, he stuck close to me for a long time; but I never found anything in him that could at all be found fault with.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:7
verses.text: Nevertheless, since it has been for long my deliberate determination to interfere in no man's favour with a view to his undertaking the burden of pastoral care, I can but follow up your election with my prayers that Almighty God, who is ever prescient of our future doings, may supply you with a pastor such that in his tongue and manners you may be able to find pastures of divine exhortation; one in whose disposition humility may shine forth together with rectitude, and severity with loving-kindness; one who may be able to shew you the way of life not in his speaking only but also in his living; that so from his example your love may learn to sigh with longing for the eternal country.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:8
verses.text: Wherefore, most dear sons, we, warned by our sense of the censorship of our office, urge you in this matter of getting yourselves a bishop that none of you look to your own gain without regard to the common advantage, lest, if any one is eager after his own individual interest, he should be deceived by a frivolous estimate: for the mind that is bound by cupidity does not examine with a free judgment a person's claims to preference.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:9
verses.text: Considering, therefore, what things are profitable for all, pay ye ever in all things most complete obedience to him whom Divine grace may put over you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:10
verses.text: For, when once put over you, he must not be further judged by you; though now he ought to be the more thoroughly judged as he may not be judged hereafter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:11
verses.text: But, when with God's leave a pastor has been consecrated for you, commit ye yourselves to him with all your heart, and in him serve the Lord the Almighty, who has put him over you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:12
verses.text: But, inasmuch as supernal judgment is wont to provide pastors for peoples according to their deservings, do you seek spiritual things, love heavenly things, despise things temporal and fugitive; and hold it for most certain that you will have a pastor who shall please God, if you in your own doings please God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:13
verses.text: Lo, all the things of this world, which we used to hear from the sacred page were doomed to perish, we see already ruined.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:14
verses.text: Cities are overthrown, camps uprooted, churches destroyed; and no tiller of the ground inhabits our land.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:15
verses.text: Among ourselves who are left, very few in number, the sword of man incessantly rages along with calamities wherewith we are smitten from above.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:16
verses.text: Thus we see before our eyes the evils which we long ago heard should come upon the world, and the very regions of the earth have become as pages of books to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:17
verses.text: In the passing away, then, of all things, we ought to take thought how that all that we have loved was nothing.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:18
verses.text: View, therefore, with anxious heart the approaching day of the eternal judge, and by repenting anticipate its terrors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:19
verses.text: Wash away with tears the status of all your transgressions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:20
verses.text: Allay by temporal lamentation the wrath that hangs over you eternally.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:21
verses.text: For our loving Creator, when He shall come for judgment, will comfort us with all the greater favour as He sees now that we are punishing ourselves for our own transgressions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:22
verses.text: We are now sending to you, by the favour of God, John our subdeacon, the bearer of these presents, to this end;â€”that, with the help of Almighty God, he may see to your bishop-elect being consecrated after the manner of his predecessor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 13:23
verses.text: For, as we demand our rights from others, so we conserve their several rights to all.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:1
verses.text: Epistle XXX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:2
verses.text: To John, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:4
verses.text: Inasmuch as it is manifest that the Apostolic See is, by the ordering of God, set over all Churches, there is, among our manifold cares, especial demand for our attention, when our decision is awaited with a view to the consecration of a bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:5
verses.text: Now on the death of Laurentius, bishop of the church of Mediolanum, the clergy reported to us that they had unanimously agreed in the election of our son Constantius, their deacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:6
verses.text: But, their report not having been subscribed, it becomes necessary, that we may omit nothing in the way of caution, for thee to proceed to Genua (Genoa), supported by the authority of this order.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:7
verses.text: And, inasmuch as there are many Milanese at  present there under stress of barbarian ferocity, thou must call them together, and enquire into their wishes in common.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 14:8
verses.text: And, if no diversity of opinion separates them from the unanimity of the electionâ€”that is to say, if thou ascertainest that the desire and consent of all continues in favour of our aforesaid son, Constantius,â€”then thou art to cause him to be consecrated by his own bishops, as ancient usage requires, with the assent of our authority, and the help of the Lord; to the end that through the observance of such custom both the Apostolic See may retain the power belonging to it, and at the same time may not diminish the rights which it has conceded to others.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:2
verses.text: To Romanus, Patrician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:3
verses.text: Gregory to Romanus, Patrician, and Exarch of Italy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:4
verses.text: We believe that your Excellency is already aware of the death of Laurentius, bishop of the church of Mediolanum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:5
verses.text: And since, so far as we have learnt from the report of the clergy, all have agreed in the election of our son Constantius, deacon of the same church, it was necessary for us, for keeping up old usage, to send a soldier of our church, to cause him in whose favour he finds the will and consent of all to concur unanimously to be consecrated by his own bishops, as ancient usage requires, though still with our assent.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:6
verses.text: Wherefore, greeting you with fatherly affection as in duty bound, we request your Excellency to vouchsafe your support, justice approving, to the aforesaid Constantius, whether elected or not, whenever need may arise; to the end that this service may both exalt you here before your enemies, and commend you beforehand in the future life before God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:7
verses.text: For he is one of mine, and was once associated with me on very intimate terms.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 15:8
verses.text: And you ought to hold as yours, and to love peculiarly, those whom you know to be ours.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:2
verses.text: To Honoratus, Archdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:3
verses.text: Gregory to Honoratus, Archdeacon of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:4
verses.text: The mandates of ourselves and of our predecessor had reached thy Love not long ago, in which thou wert acquitted of the charges calumniously brought against thee; and we ordered thee to be reinstated without any dispute in the order of thy rank.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:5
verses.text: But, inasmuch as again after no great lapse of time, thou camest to the city of Rome complaining of some improper proceedings among you concerning the alienation of sacred vessels, and as, while we had persons with us here who might have replied to thy objections, Natalis, thy bishop, departed this life, we have judged it necessary to confirm further by this present letter those same mandates, both our predecessor's and our own, which (as has been said) we sent not long ago for thy acquittal.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:6
verses.text: Wherefore, acquitting thee fully of all the charges brought against thee, we will that thou continue without any dispute in the rank of thy order, so that the question raised by the aforesaid man may not on any pretext prejudice thee in the least degree.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:7
verses.text: Moreover, as to the heads of thy complaint, we have straitly charged Antoninus, subdeacon and rector in your parts of the patrimony of holy Church over which, by God's providence, we preside, that, if he should find ecclesiastical persons implicated in them, he decide these cases with the utmost strictness and authority.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 16:8
verses.text: But, in case of the business being with such persons as the vigour of ecclesiastical jurisdiction cannot reach, he is to deposit the proofs under each particular head among the public acts, and transmit them to us without any delay, that, being accurately informed, we may know how, with the help of Christ, to dispose of the matter.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:2
verses.text: To Dynamius, Patrician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:3
verses.text: Gregory to Dynamius, Patrician of Gaul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:4
verses.text: He who administers faithfully what is other's shews how well he dispenses what is his own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:5
verses.text: And this your Glory makes manifest to us in that, intent on your annual offering, you have rendered the blessed Peter, Prince of the apostles, the fruits of his revenues.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:6
verses.text: In paying him what is his faithfully, you have made these gifts to him your own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:7
verses.text: For indeed it becomes the glorious people of this earth who think of eternal glory so to act that in virtue of their excelling in temporal power, they may procure for themselves a reward that is not temporal.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:8
verses.text: Accordingly, addressing to you the greeting which we owe, we implore Almighty God both to replenish your life with present good, and to extend it to the lofty joys of eternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:9
verses.text: For we have received through our son Hilarus (al Hilarius) of the aforesaid revenues of our Church four hundred Gallican solidi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:10
verses.text: We now send you as the benediction of the blessed apostle Peter a small cross, wherein are inserted benefits from his chains, which for a time bound his neck: but may  they loose yours from sins for ever.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 17:11
verses.text: Moreover in its four parts round about are contained benefits from the gridiron of the blessed Laurence, whereon he was burnt, that it, whereon his body was consumed by fire for the truth's sake, may inflame your soul to the love of the Lord.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, subdeacon of Campania.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:4
verses.text: Our brother and fellow-bishop Paul has often requested us to allow him to return to his own church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:5
verses.text: And, having perceived this to be reasonable, we have thought it needful to accede to his petition.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:6
verses.text: Consequently let thy Experience convene the clergy of the Neapolitan church, to the end that they may choose two or three of their number, and not omit to send them hither for the election of a bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:7
verses.text: But let them also intimate, in their communication to us, that those whom they send represent them all in this election, so that their church may have its own bishop validly ordained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:8
verses.text: For we cannot allow it to be any longer without a ruler of its own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:9
verses.text: Should they perchance try in any way to set aside thy admonition, bring to bear on them the vigour of ecclesiastical discipline.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:10
verses.text: For he will be giving proof of his own perverseness, whosoever does not of his own accord assent to this proceeding.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:11
verses.text: Moreover, cause to be given to the aforesaid Paul, our brother and fellow-bishop, one hundred solidi, and one little orphan boy, to be selected by himself, for his labour in behalf of the same church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:12
verses.text: Further, admonish those who are to come hither as representing all for the election of a bishop, to remember that they must bring with them all the episcopal vestments, and also as much money as they may foresee to be necessary for him who may be elected bishop to have to his own use.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 18:13
verses.text: But lose no time in despatching those of the clergy who are selected as we have said, that, seeing that there are present here divers nobles of the city of Naples, we may treat with them concerning the election of a bishop, and take counsel together with the help of the Lord.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19:2
verses.text: To Sabinus, Guardian (Defensorem).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19:3
verses.text: Gregory to Sabinus, Guardian of Sardinia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19:4
verses.text: Certain serious matters having come to our ears which require canonical correction, we therefore charge thy Experience not to neglect to cause Januarius, our brother and fellow-bishop, together with John the notary, to appear before us with all speed, all excuses being laid aside, that in his presence what has been reported to us may be subjected to a thorough investigation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19:5
verses.text: Further, if the religious women Pompeiana and Theodosia, according to their request, should wish to come hither, afford them your succour in all ways, that they may be able, through your assistance, to accomplish their desires: but especially be careful by all means to bring with you the most eloquent Isidore, as he has requested, that, the merits of his case which he is known to have against the Church of Caralis having been fully gone into, he may be able to have it legally terminated.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19:6
verses.text: Furthermore, some personal misdemeanours having been reported to us of the presbyter Epiphanius, it is necessary for you to investigate everything diligently, and to make haste to bring at the same time with you the women with whom he is said to have sinned, or others whom you suppose to know anything about the matter; that so the truth may be clearly laid open to the rigour of ecclesiastical discipline.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 19:7
verses.text: Now you will take care to accomplish all these things so efficiently as to lay yourself open to no blame for negligence, knowing that it will be entirely at your peril if this our order should in any way be slackly executed.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:2
verses.text: To Libertinus, Praefect.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:3
verses.text: Gregory to Libertinus, Praefect of Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:4
verses.text: From the very beginning of your administration God has willed you to go forth to vindicate His cause, and of His mercy has reserved for you this reward, with praise attending it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:5
verses.text: For it is reported that one Nasas, a most wicked Jew, has with a temerity that calls for punishment erected an altar under the name of the blessed Elias, and by sacrilegious seduction has enticed many Christians to worship there; nay, has also, it is said, acquired Christian slaves, and devoted them to his own service and profit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:6
verses.text: Whilst, then, he ought to have been most severely punished for such great crimes, the glorious Justinus, soothed (as has been written to us) by the charm of avarice, put off avenging the injury done to God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:7
verses.text: But let your Glory institute a strict examination into all these things, and, if it should be found manifest that such things have been done, make haste to visit  them most strictly and corporally on this wicked Jew, in such sort that you may thereby both conciliate the favour of God to yourself, and shew yourself by this example, to your own reward, a model to posterity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:8
verses.text: Moreover, set at liberty, without any equivocation, according to the injunctions of the laws, whatever Christian slaves it shall appear that he has acquired; lest (which God forbid) the Christian religion should be polluted by being subjected to Jews.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 20:9
verses.text: Do you therefore with all speed correct these things most strictly, that not only may we give thanks to you for this discipline, but also bear testimony to your goodness in case of need.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:1
verses.text: Epistle XLV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:2
verses.text: To Andrew, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:3
verses.text: Gregory to Andrew, Bishop of Tarentum [Taranto, in Calabria].

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:4
verses.text: A man may look without alarm to the tribunal of the eternal Judge, if only, conscious of his own guilt, he strives to pacify Him by befitting penitence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:5
verses.text: Now that thou hadst a concubine we find to be manifestly true, with regard to whom also an adverse suspicion has arisen in the minds of some.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:6
verses.text: But, since in doubtful cases judgment ought not to be absolute, we have chosen to leave the matter to thine own conscience.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:7
verses.text: If, then, after being constituted in sacred orders thou rememberest having been defiled by carnal intercourse, thou must resign the dignity of priesthood, nor presume by any means to approach its ministration, knowing that thou wilt administer it to the peril of thy soul, and without doubt have to render an account to our God, if, being conscious of this crime, thou shouldest desire to continue in the order wherein thou art, concealing the truth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:8
verses.text: Wherefore we again exhort thee that, if thou knowest thyself to have been deceived by the craft of the ancient foe, thou hasten to overcome him, while thou mayest, by adequate penitence, lest, as we hope may not be, thou be reckoned as partner with him in the day of judgment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:9
verses.text: If, however, thou art not conscious of this guilt, thou must needs continue in the order wherein thou art.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:10
verses.text: Furthermore, since, against due order, thou didst doom a woman on the Church-roll to be cruelly beaten with cudgels, although we do not think that she died eight months afterwards, yet, because thou hast had no regard to thy order, we therefore sentence thee to abstain for two months from the administration of mass.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:11
verses.text: Meanwhile, being suspended from thy office, it will become thee to weep for what thou hast done.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 21:12
verses.text: For it is very right that, now that the examples of praiseworthy priests do not provoke thee to the tranquil rectitude befitting thy position, at any rate the medicine of correction should compel thee.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, Bishop of Calliopolis [Gallipoli, in Calabria].

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:4
verses.text: From the reports sent to us by thy Fraternity it appears that Andrew, our brother and fellow-bishop, undoubtedly had a concubine.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:5
verses.text: But, since it is uncertain whether he has touched her while constituted in sacred orders, it is necessary that thou shouldest warn him with earnest exhortation that, if he knows himself to have had intercourse with her while in sacred orders, he should retire from the office which he holds, and minister no longer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:6
verses.text: And if, though conscious of having done this thing, he should conceal his sin and presume to minister, let him know that peril hangs over his soul in the divine judgment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:7
verses.text: As to the woman on the Church-roll, whom he caused to be chastised with cudgels, though we do not believe that she died eight months afterwards, yet, since he caused her to be thus punished inconsistently with his sacred calling, do thou suspend him for two months from the solemnization of mass, that at any rate this disgrace may teach him how to behave himself in future.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:8
verses.text: Moreover, the clergy of the aforesaid bishop, in a petition presented to us, which is subjoined below, allege that they endure much ill-treatment from him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:9
verses.text: Wherefore let thy Fraternity take care to ascertain all these things accurately, and so to correct and arrange them in a reasonable way that they may be under no necessity hereafter of resorting hither on account of this matter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 22:10
verses.text: In the month of July, indiction 11.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:2
verses.text: To the Clergy of the Church of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:3
verses.text: Gregory to the clergy, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:4
verses.text: Having read your letter, beloved, we learn  that you have made choice of Honoratus your archdeacon; and know ye that it is altogether pleasing to us that you have chosen for the order of episcopacy a man tried of old and of grave manner of life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:5
verses.text: We too join with you in approbation of his personal character, inasmuch as it is already known to us; and it has been our own wish also that he should be ordained as your priest according to your desire.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:6
verses.text: For which cause we exhort you to persist in his election without any ambiguity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:7
verses.text: Nor ought any circumstances to disincline you from his person, since, as this laudable choice is now approved, so it will impose both a burden on your souls and a stain of unfaithfulness on your reputation, if any one should seduce you (which God forbid) to turn aside your love from him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:8
verses.text: But as to those who are not at one with you in this desired election, we have caused them to be admonished by Antoninus our subdeacon, that they may be able to agree with you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:9
verses.text: To him also we have already given our injunctions as to what ought to be done with respect to the person of our brother and fellow-bishop Malchus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:10
verses.text: But, inasmuch as we have ourselves also written to him, we believe that he will without delay keep himself quiet from disquieting you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 23:11
verses.text: If by any chance he should in any way whatever neglect to obey, his contumacy will in every way be mulcted with the utmost rigour of canonical punishment.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:2
verses.text: To Columbus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:3
verses.text: Gregory to Columbus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:4
verses.text: Even before receiving thy Fraternity's letter, I knew thee from the report of thy deserved reputation to be a good servant of God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:5
verses.text: And now that I have received it, I understand more fully that what fame had already spread abroad was well founded; and I greatly rejoice in thy deserts, in that thou exhibitest manners and deeds that testify to a praiseworthy life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:6
verses.text: Since, then, I feel that these things are conferred on thee by the Supernal Majesty, I congratulate thee; and I bless God our Creditor, who denies not the gifts of His mercy to His humble servants.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:7
verses.text: On this account I declare it to be true that thy Fraternity so kindles me with the flame of charity to love thee, and my spirit is so united to thee, that I both desire to see thee and am also with thee in heart, though absent.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:8
verses.text: Thou perceivest in thine own thoughts that this is so.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:9
verses.text: For in truth unity of minds in charity has power to unite more than bodily presence can.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:10
verses.text: Furthermore, that with thy whole mind, thy whole heart, thy whole soul, thou cleavest and art devoted to the Apostolic See I am now assured, as, indeed before thy letter had borne testimony to the fact, I plainly knew.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:11
verses.text: Wherefore, first addressing thee with the greeting of charity which is due, I exhort thee not to cease to be mindful of what thou hast promised to the blessed Peter, Prince of the apostles.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:12
verses.text: Wherefore be thou urgent with the primate of thy synod, that boys be in no wise admitted to sacred orders, lest they fall by so much the more dangerously as they hasten more speedily to mount to higher places.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:13
verses.text: Let there be no venality in ordination: let not the influence or entreaty of any persons obtain anything in contravention of these our prohibitions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:14
verses.text: For without doubt God is offended if any one is promoted to sacred orders, not for merit, but by favour (which God forbid) or venality.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:15
verses.text: If, then, thou art aware of these things being done, keep not silence, but oppose them urgently; since, if perchance thou shouldest neglect them, or conceal them when known of, the chain of sin will bind not those alone who do such things, but no light guilt before God will touch thee also in the matter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:16
verses.text: If, then, anything of the kind is committed, it ought to be restrained by canonical punishment, lest so great a wickedness, with sin in others, acquire strength from connivance.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:17
verses.text: I have, therefore, the sooner given leave of departure to the bearer of these presents, Victorinus, thy Fraternity's deacon, whom I think to be thy imitator, and whom I have received with charity; and by him I have transmitted to thee for a blessing keys of the blessed Peter, in which something from his chains is included.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 24:18
verses.text: Lastly, with regard to the unity and peace of the council which, under God, you are taking measures to assemble, let thy Charity rejoice my mind by informing me of everything particularly.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:1
verses.text: Epistle XLIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:2
verses.text: To Adeodatus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:3
verses.text: Gregory to Adeodatus, Primate bishop of the province of Numidia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:4
verses.text: After what manner the charity of affection has bound your Fraternity to usward the tenour of your letters has evidently shewn; and they have afforded us great matter of rejoicing, in that we have found them to be composed in a spirit of loving-kindness, and to glow with affection well-pleasing to God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:5
verses.text: As, then, we have briefly said, the epistle which you have addressed to us has so laid open your mind that its author might be supposed not to be absent from us at all.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:6
verses.text: For, indeed, persons are not to be accounted absent whose feelings are not at variance with mutual charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:7
verses.text: And though, as you say in your letter, neither your strength nor your age allow you to come to us, that we might be gratified by the bodily presence of your Fraternity, yet, seeing that we are one with you and you with us in feeling, we are entirely present one to the other, while we see each other in a mind made one through love.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:8
verses.text: Furthermore, greeting your Fraternity with the suitable affection of charity, we exhort you that you study with all your heart so to acquit yourself wisely in the office of primacy which under God you hold, that it may both profit your soul to have attained to this rank, and that you may stand out as a good example for imitation to others in the future.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:9
verses.text: Be, then, especially careful with regard to ordination; and by no means admit any to aspire to sacred orders but such as are somewhat advanced in age and pure in deeds, lest perchance they cease for ever to be what they immaturely haste to be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:10
verses.text: For you must first examine the life and manners of those who are to be placed in any sacred order; and, that you may be able to admit such as are worthy to this office, let not the influence or the entreaty of any persons whatever inveigle  you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:11
verses.text: But before all things it behoves you to be cautious that no venality may have place in ordination, lest (which God forbid) the greater danger hang over both the ordained and the ordainers.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:12
verses.text: If ever, then, there is need for such things to be taken in hand, call grave and experienced men into your counsels, and consider the matter in common deliberation with them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:13
verses.text: And before all others it is fit that you should in all cases call in Columbus our brother and fellow-bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:14
verses.text: For we believe that, if you shall have done what is to be done with his advice, no one will find anything in any way to find fault with in you; and know ye that it will be as acceptable to us as if it had been done with our advice; inasmuch as his life and manners have in all respects so approved themselves to us that it is clearly apparent to all that what is done with his consent will be darkened by no blot of faultiness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:15
verses.text: But the bearer of these presents, Victorinus, deacon of our fellow-bishop above-named, has been such a herald of your merits as exceedingly to refresh our spirits with regard to your behaviour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:16
verses.text: And we pray the Almighty Lord to cause the good that has been reported of you to shine forth more fully in operation as well-pleasing to Him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 25:17
verses.text: When, therefore, the council which you are taking measures to assemble has, with the succor of God, been brought to a conclusion, rejoice us by telling of its unity and concord, and give us information on all points.
