chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26:1
verses.text: Epistle LI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26:2
verses.text: To Maximianus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26:3
verses.text: Gregory to Maximinianus, Bishop of Syracuse.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26:4
verses.text: My brethren who live with me familiarly urge me by all means to write something briefly about the miracles of the Fathers done in Italy, which we have heard of.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26:5
verses.text: With this view I am in great need of the assistance of your Charity, to mention to me shortly what comes back to your memory, and what you happen to have known.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26:6
verses.text: For I remember your telling me something, which I have now forgotten, about the Lord Abbot Nonnosus, who was with the Lord Anastasius of Pentomi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 26:7
verses.text: And therefore this, or anything else, I beg thee to communicate to me by letter without delay, if indeed thou art not intending to come to me thyself shortly.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:1
verses.text: Epistle LIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:4
verses.text: Though consideration of the case moves me, yet charity also impels me to write, since I have written once and again to my most holy brother the lord John, but have received no letter from him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:5
verses.text: For some one else, a secular person, addressed me under his name; seeing that, if those were really his letters, I have not been vigilant, having believed of him something far different from what I have found.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:6
verses.text: For I had written about the case of the most reverend presbyter John, and about the questions of the monks of Isauria, one of whom, being in priest's orders,  has been beaten with clubs in your church; and thy most holy Fraternity (as appears from the signature of the letter) has written back to me professing ignorance of what I wrote about.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:7
verses.text: At this reply I was exceedingly astonished, revolving within myself in silence, if he speaks the truth, what can be worse than that such things should be done against the servants of God, and even he who was close at hand should not know? For what excuse can a shepherd have if the wolf devours the sheep and the shepherd knows it not? But, if your Holiness knew both what I referred to in my letter and what had been done, whether against John the presbyter or against Athanasius, monk of Isauria and presbyter, and wrote to me, I know not; what can I reply to this, since the Truth says through His Scripture, The mouth that lieth slayeth the soul (Wisd.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:8
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:9
verses.text: 11)? I demand of thee, most holy brother; has that so great abstinence of thine come to this, that by denial thou wouldest hide from thy brother what thou knewest to have been done? Had it not been better that flesh should go into that mouth for food, than that falsehood should come out of it for deceiving a neighbour; especially when the Truth says, Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth a man (Matth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:10
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:11
verses.text: 11)? But far be it from me to believe anything of the kind of your most holy heart.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:12
verses.text: Those letters were headed with your name, but I do not think they were yours.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:13
verses.text: I had written to the most blessed lord John; but I believe that that familiar of yours has replied,â€”that youngster, who as yet has learnt nothing about God; who knows not the bowels of charity; who in his wicked doings is accused by all; who daily lays snares against the deaths of divers people by means of concealed wills; who neither fears God nor regards men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:14
verses.text: Believe me, most holy brother, you must first correct this man, that from the example of those who are near to you those who are not near may be better amended.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:15
verses.text: Do not give ear to his tongue: he ought to be directed after the counsel of your holiness; not your holiness swayed by his words.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:16
verses.text: For, if you listen to him, I know that you cannot have peace with your brethren.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:17
verses.text: For I, as my conscience bears me witness, wish to quarrel with no man; and with all my power I avoid it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:18
verses.text: And, though I desire exceedingly to be at peace with all mankind, it is especially so with you, whom I exceedingly love, if only you are yourself the person whom I knew.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:19
verses.text: For, if you do not observe the canons, and wish to tear to pieces the statutes of the Fathers, I know not who you are.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:20
verses.text: So act, then, most holy and most dear brother, that we may mutually recognize each other, lest, if the ancient foe should move us two to take offence, he slay many through his most atrocious victory.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:21
verses.text: As for me, to shew that I seek to do nothing in a haughty spirit, if that youngster of whom I have before spoken did not hold the topmost place of evil doing with thy Fraternity, I could meanwhile have passed over in silence what is ready to my hand from the canons, and have sent back to thee with confidence the persons who came to me at the first, knowing that your Holiness would receive them with charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:22
verses.text: But even now I say; Either receive these same persons, restoring them to their orders, and leaving them in quiet; or, if perchance thou art unwilling to do this, observe in their case the statutes of the Fathers and the definitions of the canons, putting aside all altercation with me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:23
verses.text: But, if thou shouldest do neither, we indeed are unwilling to bring on a quarrel, but still do not shun one if it comes from your side.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:24
verses.text: Moreover your Fraternity knows well what the canons say about bishops who desire to inspire fear by blows.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:25
verses.text: For we have been made shepherds, not persecutors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:26
verses.text: And the excellent preacher says, Argue, beseech, rebuke, with all longsuffering and doctrine (2 Tim.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:27
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:28
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:29
verses.text: But new and unheard of is this preaching, which exacts faith by blows.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:30
verses.text: But I need not speak at length by letter about these things, since I have sent my most beloved son, the deacon Sabinianus, as my representative in ecclesiastical matters, to the threshold of our lords; and he will speak with you about everything more particularly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:31
verses.text: Unless you are disposed to wrangle with us, you will find him prepared for all that is just.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 27:32
verses.text: Him I commend to your Blessedness, that he at least may find that lord John whom I knew in the royal city.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:1
verses.text: Epistle LVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, Bishop of Ravenna.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:4
verses.text: It is not long since certain things had been  told us about thy Fraternity concerning which we remember having declared ourselves in full, when Castorius, notary of the holy church over which we preside, went into your parts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:5
verses.text: For it had come to our ears that some things were being done in your church contrary to custom and to the way of humility, which alone, as you well know, exalts the priestly office.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:6
verses.text: Now, if your Wisdom had received our admonitions kindly or with episcopal seriousness, you ought not to have been incensed by them, but have corrected these same things with thanks to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:7
verses.text: For it is contrary to ecclesiastical use, if even unjust correction (the which be far from us) is not most patiently borne.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:8
verses.text: But your Fraternity has been too much moved; and when, in the swelling of thy heart, as if to justify thyself, thou wrotest that thou didst not use the pallium except after the sons of the Church had been dismissed from the sacristy, and at the time of mass, and in solemn litanies, thou madest acknowledgment in words with most manifest truth of having usurped something contrary to the usage of the Church in general.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:9
verses.text: For how can it be that at a time of ashes and sackcloth, through the streets among the noises of the people thou couldest do lawfully what thou hast disclaimed the doing of as being unlawful in the assembly of the poor and nobles, and in the sacristy of the Church? Yet this, dearest brother, is not, we think, unknown to thee; that it has hardly ever been heard of any metropolitan in any parts of the world that he has claimed to himself the use of the pallium except at the time of mass.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:10
verses.text: And that you knew well this custom of the Church in general you have shewn most plainly by your epistles, in which you have sent to us appended the precept of our predecessor John of blessed memory, to the effect that all the customs conceded in the way of privilege to you and your church by our predecessors should be retained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:11
verses.text: You acknowledge, then, that the custom of the Church in general is different, seeing that you claim the right of doing what you do on the score of privilege.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:12
verses.text: Thus, as we think, we can have no remaining doubtfulness in this matter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:13
verses.text: For either the usage of all metropolitans should be observed also by thy Fraternity, or, if thou sayest that something has been specially conceded to thy church, it is for your side to shew the precept of former pontiffs of the Roman City wherein these things have been conceded to the Church of Ravenna.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:14
verses.text: But, if this is not shewn, it remains, seeing that you establish your claim to do such things on the score neither of general custom nor of privilege, that you prove yourself to have usurped in what you have done.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:15
verses.text: And what shall we say to the future judge, most beloved brother, if we defend the use of that heavy yoke and chain on our neck with a view, I do not say to ecclesiastical, but to a certain secular dignity; judging ourselves to be lowered if we are without so great a weight even for a short space of time? We desire to be adorned with the pallium, being, it may be, unadorned in character; whereas nothing shines more splendidly on a bishop's neck than humility.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:16
verses.text: It is therefore the duty of thy Fraternity, if thou art firmly determined to defend thy honours with any kind of arguments, either to follow the use of the generality without written authority, or to defend thyself under privileges shewn in writing.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:17
verses.text: Or, if lastly thou doest neither, we will not have thee set an example of presumption of this sort to other metropolitans.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:18
verses.text: But, lest thou shouldest perchance think that we, in thus writing to you, have neglected what belongs to fraternal charity, know ye that careful search has been made in our archives for the privileges of thy Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:19
verses.text: And indeed some things have been found, sufficient to obviate entirely the aims of thy Fraternity, but nothing to support the contentions of your Church on the points in question.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:20
verses.text: For even concerning the very custom of thy Church which thou allegest against us, which custom we wrote before should be proved on your side, we would have you know that we have already taken thought sufficiently, having questioned our sons, Peter the deacon and Gaudiosus the primicerius, and also Michael the guardian (defensorem) of our see, or others who on various commissions have been sent by our predecessors to Ravenna; and they have most positively denied that thou hast done these things in their presence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:21
verses.text: It is therefore apparent that what was done in secret must have been an unlawful usurpation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:22
verses.text: Hence what has been latently introduced can have no firm ground to justify its continuance.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:23
verses.text: What things, then, thou or thy predecessors have presumed to do superfluously do thou, having regard to charity, and with brotherly kindness, study to correct.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:24
verses.text: To no degree attemptâ€”I do not say of thine own  accord, but after the fashion set by others, even thy predecessors,â€”to deviate from the rule of humility.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:25
verses.text: For, to sum up shortly what I have said above, I admonish thee to this effect; that unless thou canst shew that this has been allowed thee by my predecessors in the way of privilege, thou presume not any more to use the pallium in the streets, lest thou come not to have even for mass what thou audaciously usurpest even in the streets.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:26
verses.text: But as to thy sitting in the sacristy, and receiving the sons of the Church with the pallium on (which thing thy Fraternity has both done and disclaimed), we now for the present make no complaint; since, following the decision of synods, we refuse to punish minor faults, which are denied.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:27
verses.text: Yet we know this to have been done once and again, and we prohibit its being done any more.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:28
verses.text: But let thy Fraternity take careful heed, lest presumption which in its commencement is pardoned be more severely visited if it proceeds further.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:29
verses.text: Furthermore, you have complained that certain of the sacerdotal order in the city of Ravenna are involved in serious criminal charges.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:30
verses.text: Their case we desire thee either to examine on the spot, or to send them hither (unless, indeed, difficulty of proof owing to the distance of the places stands in the way of this), that the case may be examined here.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:31
verses.text: But if, relying on the patronage of great people, which we do not believe, they should scorn to submit to thy judgment or to come to us, and should refuse contumaciously to answer to the charges made against them, we desire that after thy second and third admonition, thou interdict them from the ministry of the sacred office, and report to us in writing of their contumacy, that we may deliberate how thou oughtest to make a thorough enquiry into their doings, and correct them according to canonical definitions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:32
verses.text: Let, therefore, thy Fraternity know that we are most fully absolved from responsibility in this case, seeing that we have committed to you a thorough investigation of the matter; and that, if all their sins should pass unpunished, the whole weight of this enquiry redounds to the peril of thy soul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:33
verses.text: And know, beloved, that thou wilt have no excuse at the future judgment, if thou dost not correct the excesses of thy clergy with the utmost severity of canonical strictness, and if thou allowest any against whom such excesses shall have been proved to profane sacred orders any longer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:34
verses.text: Further, what you have written in defence of the use of napkins by your clergy is strenuously opposed by our own clergy, who say that this has never been granted to any other Church whatever, and that neither have the clergy of Ravenna, either there or in the Roman city, presumed, to their knowledge, in any such way, nor, if it has been attempted in the way of furtive usurpation, does it form a precedent.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:35
verses.text: But, even though there had been such presumption in any church whatever, they assert that it ought to be corrected, not being by grant of the Roman pontiff, but merely a surreptitious presumption.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:36
verses.text: But we, to save the honour of thy Fraternity, though against the wish of our aforesaid clergy, still allow the use of napkins to your first deacons (whose former use of them has been testified to us by some), but only when in attendance upon thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 28:37
verses.text: The use of them, at any other time, or by any other persons, we most strictly prohibit.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:1
verses.text: Epistle LVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:2
verses.text: From John, Bishop of Ravenna to Pope Gregory.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:3
verses.text: My most reverend fellow-servant Castorius, notary of your Apostolical See, has delivered to me my Lord's epistle, compounded of honey and of venom; which has yet so infixed its stings as still to leave place for healing appliances.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:4
verses.text: For my Lord, while he reproves pride and speaks of divine judgment following it, in a certain way professes himself with reason to be mild and placid.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:5
verses.text: You have alleged, then, that I, ambitious of novelty, have usurped the use of the pallium beyond what had been indulged to my predecessors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:6
verses.text: This let not the conscience of my own lord, which is governed by the divine right hand, in any way allow itself to believe; nor let him open his most sacred ears to the uncertainty of common report.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:7
verses.text: First, because I, though a sinner, still know how grave a thing it is to transgress the limits assigned to us by the Fathers, and that all elation leads to nothing but a fall.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:8
verses.text: For, if our ancestors did not tolerate pride in kings, how much more is it not to be endured in priests! Then, I remember how I was nourished in the lap and in the bosom of your most holy Roman Church, and therein by the aid of God advanced.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:9
verses.text: And how should I be so daring as to presume to oppose that most holy see, which transmits its laws to the universal Church, for maintaining whose authority, as God knows, I have seriously excited the ill-will of many enemies  against myself? But let not my most blessed lord suppose that I have attempted anything contrary to ancient custom, as is attested by many and nearly all the citizens of this city, and as the above-written most reverend notary, even though he had taken no part in the proceedings, might have testified, inasmuch as it was not till the sons of the Church were descending from the sacristy, and the deacons were coming in for proceeding immediately [to the altar] that the first deacon has been accustomed to invest the bishop of the Church of Ravenna with the pallium, which he has also been accustomed in like manner to use in solemn litanies.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:10
verses.text: Wherefore let no one endeavour to insinuate anything against me to my lord, since if any one wishes to do so, he cannot prove that any novelty has been introduced by me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:11
verses.text: For in what manner I have obeyed your commands and served your interests when cause required, may Almighty God make manifest to your most sincere heart: and I attribute it to my sins that after so many labours and difficulties which I endure within and without I should deserve to experience such a change.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:12
verses.text: But again this among other things consoles me, that most holy fathers sometimes chastise their sons for the purpose only of advancing them the more, and that, after this devotion and satisfaction, you will not only conserve to the holy Church of Ravenna her ancient privileges, but even confer greater ones in your own times.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:13
verses.text: For with respect to the napkins, the use of which by my presbyters and deacons your Apostleship alleges to be a presumption, I confess in truth that it irks me to say anything on the subject, since the truth by itself, which alone prevails with my lord, is sufficient.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:14
verses.text: For this being allowed to the smaller churches constituted around the city, the apostleship of my lord will also be able in all ways to find, if he deigns to enquire of the venerable clergy of his own first Apostolical See, that as often as priests or levites of the Church of Ravenna have come to Rome for the ordination of bishops or for business, they all have proceeded with napkins before the eyes of your most holy predecessors without any blame.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:15
verses.text: Wherefore also at the time when I, sinner as I am, was ordained there by your predecessor, all my presbyters and deacons used them while proceeding in attendance on the lord pope.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:16
verses.text: And since our God in His providence has placed all things in your hand and most pure conscience, I adjure you by the very Apostolical See, which you formerly adorned by your character, and now govern with due dignity, that you in no respect diminish on account of my deservings the privileges of the Church of Ravenna, which is intimately yours; but, even according to the voice of prophecy, let it be laid upon me and upon my father's house, according to its deserving.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:17
verses.text: I have, therefore, for your greater satisfaction, subjoined all the privileges which have been indulged by your predecessors to the holy Church of Ravenna, though none the less finding assurance in your venerable archives in reference to the times of the consecration of my predecessors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 29:18
verses.text: But now whatever, after ascertaining the truth, you may command to be done, is in God's power and yours; since I, desiring to obey the commands of my lord's Apostleship, have taken care, notwithstanding ancient custom, to abstain till I receive further orders.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30:1
verses.text: Epistle LIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30:2
verses.text: To Secundinus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30:3
verses.text: Gregory to Secundinus, Bishop of Tauromenium.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30:4
verses.text: [In Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30:5
verses.text: ]  Some time ago we ordered that the baptistery should be removed from the monastery of Saint Andrew, which is above Mascalae, because of inconvenience to the monks, and that an altar should be erected in the place where the fonts now are.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30:6
verses.text: But the carrying out of this order has been put off so far.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 30:7
verses.text: We therefore admonish thy Fraternity that thou interpose no further delay after receiving this our letter, but that the fonts themselves be filled up, and an altar at once erected there for celebration of the sacred mysteries; to the end that the aforesaid monks may be at liberty to celebrate more securely the work of God, and that our mind be not provoked against thy Fraternity for negligence.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:1
verses.text: Epistle LX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:2
verses.text: To Italica, Patrician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:3
verses.text: Gregory to Italica, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:4
verses.text: We have received your letter, which is full  of sweetness, and rejoice to hear that your Excellency is well.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:5
verses.text: Such is the sincerity of our own mind with regard to it that paternal affection does not allow us to suspect any latent ill-feeling concealed under its calmness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:6
verses.text: But may Almighty God bring it to pass, that, as we think what is good of you, so your mind may respond with good towards us, and that you may exhibit in your deeds the sweetness which you express in words.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:7
verses.text: For the most glorious health and beauty on the surface of the body profit nothing if there is a hidden sore within.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:8
verses.text: And that discord is the more to be guarded against to which exterior peace affords a bodyguard.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:9
verses.text: But as to what your Excellency in your aforesaid epistle takes pains to recall to our recollection, remember that you have been told in writing that we would not settle anything with you concerning the causes of the poor so as to cause offence, or with public clamour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:10
verses.text: We remember writing to you to this effect, and also know, God helping us how to restrain ourselves with ecclesiastical moderation from the wrangling of suits at law, and, according to that apostolical sentence, to endure joyfully the spoiling of our goods.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:11
verses.text: But this we suppose you to know; that our silence and patience will not be to the prejudice of future pontiffs after me in the affairs of the poor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:12
verses.text: Wherefore we, in fulfilment of our aforesaid promise, have already determined to keep silence on these questions; nor do we desire to mix ourselves personally in these transactions, wherein we feel that too little kindness is being shewn.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:13
verses.text: But, lest you should hence imagine, glorious daughter, that we still altogether renounce what pertains to concord, we have given directions to our son, Cyprianus the deacon, who is going to Sicily, that, if you arrange about these matters in a salutary way, and without sin to your soul, he should settle them with you by our authority, and that we should be no further vexed by the business which may thus be brought to a conclusion amicably.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 31:14
verses.text: Now may Almighty God, who well knows how to turn to possibility things altogether impossible, may He inspire you both to arrange your affairs with a view to peace, and, for the good of your soul, to consult the benefit of the poor of this Church in matters which concern them.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:1
verses.text: Epistle LXV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:2
verses.text: To Mauricius Augustus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:3
verses.text: Gregory to Mauricius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:4
verses.text: He is guilty before Almighty God who is not pure of offence towards our most serene lords in all he does and says.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:5
verses.text: I, however, unworthy servant of your Piety, speak in this my representation neither as a bishop, nor as your servant in right of the republic, but as of private right, since, most serene Lord, you have been mine since the time when you were not yet lord of all.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:6
verses.text: On the arrival here of the most illustrious Longinus, the equerry (stratore), I received the law of my lords, to which, being at the time worn out by bodily sickness, I was unable to make any reply.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:7
verses.text: In it the piety of my lords has ordained that it shall not be lawful for any one who is engaged in any public administration to enter on an ecclesiastical office.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:8
verses.text: And this I greatly commended, knowing by most evident proof that one who is in haste to desert a secular condition and enter on an ecclesiastical office is not wishing to relinquish secular affairs, but to change them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:9
verses.text: But, at its being said in the same law that it should not be lawful for him to become a monk, I was altogether surprised, seeing that his accounts can be rendered through a monastery, and it can be arranged for his debts also to be recovered from the place into which he is received.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:10
verses.text: For with whatever devout intention a person may have wished to become a monk, he should first restore what he has wrongly gotten, and take thought for his soul all the more truly as he is the more disencumbered.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:11
verses.text: It is added in the same law that no one who has been marked on the hand may become a monk.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:12
verses.text: This ordinance, I confess to my lords, has alarmed me greatly, since by  it the way to heaven is closed against many, and what has been lawful until now is made unlawful.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:13
verses.text: For there are many who are able to live a religious life even in a secular condition: but there are very many who cannot in any wise be saved with God unless they give up all things.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:14
verses.text: But what am I, in speaking thus to my lords, but dust and a worm? Yet still, feeling that this ordinance makes against God, who is the Author of all, I cannot keep silence to my lords.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:15
verses.text: For power over all men has been given from heaven to the piety of my lords to this end, that they who aspire to what is good may be helped, and that the way to heaven may be more widely open, so that an earthly kingdom may wait upon the heavenly kingdom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:16
verses.text: And lo, it is said in plain words that one who has once been marked to serve as an earthly soldier may not, unless he has either completed his service or been rejected for weakness of body, serve as the soldier of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:17
verses.text: To this, behold, Christ through me the last of His servants and of yours will answer, saying; From a notary I made thee a Count of the bodyguard; from Count of the bodyguard I made thee a Caesar; from a Caesar I made thee Emperor; and not only so, but also a father of emperors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:18
verses.text: I have committed my priests into thy hand; and dost thou withdraw thy soldiers from my service? Answer thy servant, most pious lord, I beseech thee; what wilt thou answer to thy Lord when He comes and thus speaks?  But peradventure it is believed that no one among them turns monk with a pure motive.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:19
verses.text: I, your unworthy servant, know how many soldiers who have become monks in my own days have done miracles, have wrought signs and mighty deeds.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:20
verses.text: But by this law it is forbidden that even one of such as these should become a monk.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:21
verses.text: Let my Lord enquire, I beg, what former emperor ever enacted such a law, and consider more thoroughly whether it ought to have been enacted.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:22
verses.text: And indeed it is a very serious consideration, that now at this time any are forbidden to leave the world; a time when the end of the world is drawing nigh.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:23
verses.text: For lo! there will be no delay: the heavens on fire, the earth on fire, the elements blazing, with angels and archangels, thrones and dominions, principalities and powers, the tremendous Judge will appear.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:24
verses.text: Should He remit all sins, and say only that this law has been promulged against Himself, what excuse, pray, will there be? Wherefore by the same tremendous Judge I beseech you, that all those tears, all those prayers, all those fasts, all those alms of my Lord, may not on any ground lose their lustre before the eyes of Almighty God: but let your Piety, either by interpretation or alteration, modify the force of this law, since the army of my lords against their enemies increases the more when the army of God has been increased for prayer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:25
verses.text: I indeed, being subject to your command, have caused this law to be transmitted through various parts of the world; and, inasmuch as the law itself is by no means agreeable to Almighty God, lo, I have by this my representation declared this to my most serene lords.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 32:26
verses.text: On both sides, then, I have discharged my duty, having both yielded obedience to the Emperor, and not kept silence as to what I feel in behalf of God.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:1
verses.text: Epistle LXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:2
verses.text: To Theodorus, Physician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:3
verses.text: Gregory to Theodorus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:4
verses.text: What benefits I enjoy from Almighty God and my most serene lord the Emperor my tongue cannot fully express.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:5
verses.text: For these benefits what return is it in me to make, but to love their footsteps sincerely? But, on account of my sins, by whose suggestion or counsel I know not, in the past year he has promulged such a law in his republic that whoso loves him sincerely must lament exceedingly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:6
verses.text: I could not reply to this law at the time, being sick.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:7
verses.text: But I have just now offered some suggestions to my lord.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:8
verses.text: For he enjoins that it shall be lawful for no one to become a monk who has been engaged in any public employment, for no one who is a paymaster, or who has been marked in the hand, or enrolled among the soldiers, unless perchance his military service has been completed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:9
verses.text: This law, as those say who are acquainted with old laws, Julian was the first to promulge, of whom we all know how opposed he was to God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:10
verses.text: Now if our most serene lord has done this thing because perhaps many soldiers were becoming monks, and the army was decreasing, was it by the valour of soldiers that Almighty God subjugated to him the empire of the Persians? Was it not only that his tears were heard, and that God, by an order which he knew not of, subdued to his empire the empire of the Persians?  Now it seems to me exceedingly hard that he should debar his soldiers from the service of Him who both gave him all and granted him to rule not only over soldiers but even over priests.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:11
verses.text: If his purpose is to save property  from being lost, why might not those same monasteries into which soldiers have been received pay their debts, retaining the men only for monastic profession? Since these things grieve me much, I have represented the matter to my lord.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:12
verses.text: But let your Glory take a favourable opportunity of offering him my representation privately.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:13
verses.text: For I am unwilling that it should be given publicly by my representative (responsalis), seeing that you who serve him familiarly can speak more freely and openly of what is for the good of his soul, since he is occupied with many things, and it is not easy to find his mind free from greater cares.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:14
verses.text: Do thou, then, glorious son, speak for Christ.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:15
verses.text: If thou art heard, it will be to the profit of the soul of thy aforesaid lord and of thine own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 33:16
verses.text: But if thou art not heard, thou hast profited thine own soul only.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:1
verses.text: Epistle LXVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:2
verses.text: To Domitian, Metropolitan.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:3
verses.text: Gregory to Domitian, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:4
verses.text: On receiving the letters of your most sweet Blessedness I greatly rejoiced, since they spoke much to me of sacred Scripture.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:5
verses.text: And, finding in them the dainties that I love, I greedily devoured them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:6
verses.text: Therein also were many things intermingled about external and necessary affairs.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:7
verses.text: And you have acted as though preparing a banquet for the mind so that the offered dainties might please the more from their diversity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:8
verses.text: And if indeed external affairs, like inferior and ordinary kinds of food, are less savoury, yet they have been treated by you so skilfully as to be taken gladly, since even contemptible kinds of food are usually made sweet by the sauce of one who cooks well.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:9
verses.text: Now, while the truth of the History is kept to, what I had said some time ago about its divine meaning ought not to be rejected.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:10
verses.text: For, although, since you will have it so, its meaning may not suit my case, yet, from its very context, what was said as being drawn from it may be held without hesitation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:11
verses.text: For her violator (i-e: Dinah's) is called the prince of the country (Genes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:12
verses.text: xxxiv.

Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:15
verses.text: And he also seeks her for his wife, because the evil spirit hastens to possess lawfully the soul which he has first corrupted by hidden seduction.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:16
verses.text: Wherefore the sons of Jacob, being very wroth, take their swords against the whole house of Sichem and his country (Genes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:18
verses.text: 25), because by all who have zeal those also are to be attacked who become abettors of the evil spirit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:19
verses.text: And they first enjoin on them circumcision, and afterwards, while they are sore, slay them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:20
verses.text: For severe teachers, if they know not how to moderate their zeal, though cutting off the bias of corruption by preaching, nevertheless, when delinquents already mourn for the evil they had done, are frequently still savage in roughness of discipline, and harder than they should be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:21
verses.text: For those who had already cut off their foreskins ought not to have died, since such as lament the sin of lechery, and turn the pleasure of the flesh into sorrow, ought not to experience from their teachers roughness of discipline, lest the Redeemer of the human race be Himself loved less, if in His behalf the soul is afflicted more than it should be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:22
verses.text: Hence also to these his sons Jacob says, Ye have troubled me, and made me odious to the Canaanites (Ibid.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:23
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:24
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:25
verses.text: For, when teachers still cruelly attack what the delinquents already mourn for, the weak mind's very love for its Redeemer grows cold, because it feels itself to be afflicted in that wherein of itself it does not spare itself.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:26
verses.text: So much therefore I would say in order to shew that the sense which I set forth is not improbable in connexion with the context.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:27
verses.text: But what has been inferred from the same passage by your Holiness for my comfort I gladly accept, since in the understanding of sacred Scripture whatever is not opposed to a sound faith ought not to be rejected.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:28
verses.text: For, even as from the same gold some make necklaces, some rings, and some bracelets, for ornament, so from the same knowledge of sacred Scripture different expositors, through innumerable ways of understanding it, compose as it were various ornaments, which  nevertheless all serve for the adornment of the heavenly bride.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:29
verses.text: Further, I rejoice exceedingly that your most sweet Blessedness, even though occupied with secular affairs, still brings back its genius vigilantly to the understanding of Holy Writ.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:30
verses.text: For so indeed it is needful that, if the former cannot be altogether avoided, the latter should not be altogether put aside.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:31
verses.text: But I beseech you by Almighty God, stretch out the hand of prayer to me who am labouring in so great billows of tribulation, that by your intercession I may be lifted up to the heights, who am pressed down to the depths by the weight of my sins.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:32
verses.text: Moreover, though I grieve that the Emperor of the Persians has not been converted, yet I altogether rejoice for that you have preached to him the Christian faith; since, though he has not been counted worthy to come to the light, yet your Holiness will have the reward of your preaching.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:33
verses.text: For the Ethiopian, too, goes black into the bath, and comes out black; but still the keeper of the bath receives his pay.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:34
verses.text: Further, of Mauricius you say well, that from the shadow I may know the statue; that is, that in small things I may perpend greater things.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles III 34:35
verses.text: In this matter, however, we trust him, since oaths and hostages bind his soul to us.
